ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Kangning Huang  He was a great help for this class - really amazing GIS whiz.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Kangning Huang
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Kangning Huang
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken is AMAZING! Keep him for sure. He helped me solve many many issues. I just wish we had 6 of him.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Kangning Huang
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken was great, however, I did not interact with him as much as my colleagues who I know have rave reviews of him as a TA.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Kangning Huang
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Kangning Huang
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Huang, Kangning
Instructor: Kangning Huang  I did not interact much with the TA, but I heard good things from classmates.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Huang, Kangning
Instructor: Kangning Huang  He was great!

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Kangning Huang  Incredibly patient and supportive

Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken did a great job -- very accessible, knowledgable, and helpful. He tried to be accommodating of students' schedules whenever possible, and responded to emails and other online help requests quickly.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  He has no weakness! Ken is the most friendly, cheerful, understanding and responsive TA ever! Sincerely hoping and praying he will be the TA for the spring raster class
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken was amazing! So helpful and accessible, even outside his office hours. He really went out of his way to help us solve problems.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  He really wants to help you and he does a great job of patiently making sure you understand something.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Great TA! Very responsive, patient, and knowledgable.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Responsive, clear, kind, patient, great!
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken was extremely patient and helpful. I really appreciated all his help.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Very helpful and generous with his time.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken is very helpful and understanding.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  The teaching assistant for this course was helpful whenever I had questions. He was very communicative and I knew exactly where to find him if I required support.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken is the BEST! So patient, kind, approachable. Couldn't have asked for a better TA.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  He had a good understanding of the concepts and was quite patient with the students and would sacrifice his time to assist whenever required.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  He was very helpful and always patient!
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Strength: always eager to help student No weakness, but it would be more useful if Ken can run more office hours.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  He was very helpful but I wish he was more available.
Instructor: Kangning Huang  Ken was extremely well versed in the topic, if difficult to schedule time with. I happen to have class during his office hours, making it difficult to seek help from him.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: While the instructor was responsive, responses were not always clear or may not have always addressed the problem. The instructor was mainly available over an internet platform, Piazza, which was not conducive to getting help while working on a project.

I thought this class was incredibly helpful. Expect the projects to take up a lot of time, but because I love visual learning, maps and formatting, I loved working on the projects. It is a bit difficult to learn GIS in the lecture setting, so when possible, follow along what dana is doing with GIS on your laptop. I am best when I learn by doing, so this helped me out. It was harder and harder to follow along though later in the semester, so I just took in depth notes on the processes on my computer.

-I think Dana's actually very good at explaining the concepts and techniques in person and I was motivated (if stressed) by his paternal expectations for us. His absence from campus was sometimes frustrating, especially because the activation energy to document errors and post them to Piazza, then doing the back-and-forth to try to troubleshoot them, is higher than showing the errors to someone in person. -I was EXTREMELY frustrated by the software we used in the courseparticularly using ArcGIS via Virtual Box. Its totally absurd that ESRI has a monopoly on this software and is able to get away with 80s-era software bugs, with not making it available to Mac users, etc. Its also strange that the best solution that Yale ITS has come up with is so prone to problems. Software malfunctions and obstacles stressed me out to no end and greatly impeded my learning in the course until sometime in November, when I developed systems to navigate and mitigate the problems, and when I was able to catch up with techniques the rest of the class had mastered. -I LOVED the model-building section of the class; this was by far the most satisfying. (More on this in a moment.) -I was also frustrated by the lack of technical assistance available from CSSSI staff. Ken was absolutely invaluable and I wish Id started going to see him earlier in the semester. (I also wish Id organized my weekly schedule to leave Mondays and Tuesdays more available, as this was when other students worked in Sage near each other and would, apparently, troubleshoot and share ideas that I missed out on.) But Ken is just one TA and cant spend all his time on the class. Miriam was not really available for week-to-week homework problems (e.g., all the various technical glitches that come along with ArcGIS), and I only once found another person in CSSSI who could help me troubleshoot my problem (although even her solution, as it turned out, didnt helpas I found out after Id handed in the assignment). -Having us hand in pieces of the final project before the whole thing was due was a great ideaalthough I did poorly at first, these graded assignments forced me to start working on my data early on, meaning that eventually I had a grip on the project and could produce way better results. Recommendations: a)CSSSI should provide dedicated GIS assistants (more experienced students?)perhaps drawing on the other grad schools that use GIS?to offer drop-in help with longer time windows. b)Yale ITS should invest more time/resources in figuring out a bug-free or less bug-prone system to using ArcGIS on Macs, given how many students use Macs and need to use GIS. c)Past a certain week, all of the homework submissions should be using the data for the final projectsso that students can devote more time on a week-by-week basis to their projects, rather than rushing to finish each graded assignment. d)The course material should be somewhat restructured, to have students learn data collection and cleaning, the basic format of working in ArcMap, then Data Interpretation, Data Automation, and lastly Data Presentation. This would follow more organically the actual course of the project. Basically, I felt that a lot of the presentation techniques were not applicable until the very end of the course, and the focus on presenting so early on was a distraction from the task of collection, cleaning, and handling the data. The model-building is also such a valuable part of the course that I think we could have spent another week on models (perhaps having, first, a simple model due, but then being asked to create a far more complex model). e)Recommend earlier that students work on projects in pairs, and use Powerpoint for designing most submissions.

The class was great, I have learned so many great skills. Dana Tomlin explains concepts and tools extremely well. He is very accessible, and willing to help with any problem that comes up. My only complaint is some disorganization around the grading process. The grading feels very arbitrary, and it is difficult to understand why I got the grades I did, and what I could have done to make them better.

The teacher is extremely responsive and he does a lot to help you with the material. At the same time he is also very cryptic when he explains assignments and the grading system. If he doesn't want us to know exactly what he's looking for because he wants us to figure things out on our own or make our own decisions, I think it would be better to be upfront about it.
Dana's teaching style was interesting. Instead of a straightforward back-and-forth, he would rely on competition to push each other.
GIS is important to many of us. The teaching style was definitely interesting (frustrating at times), but we all challenged and learned a lot.

Definitely struggled with this class. I would recommend it as I think it is incredibly useful for resume building and understanding this material for the future. However, unless you are planning on becoming a GIS specialist or use GIS in your work it might be better to simply take a workshop rather than a full semester.

The course was a very heavy workload and the grading I felt was arbitrary. I did not like ranking system for grades. but I do feel fairly competent at GiS now that I pretty much lived in the GIS lab all semester. I appreciate how the homework was not graded. I wouldn't have survived the workload if i was.

Question 13: While the instructor was great, I had a hard time gauging how I was doing in the course. Receiving grades (for graded assignments) throughout the semester in a timely manner would have been extremely helpful.

GIS is really an amazing tool. It's a steep learning curve but I think worthwhile. Dana is a highly accessible teacher. He gives his all to the course. His teaching style is very particular and will appeal more or less to different people. Generally I found him to be very engaging and a highly effective teaching. Way too much emphasis on the grades we got though, and while he encouraged collaboration and cooperation, he also (backhandedly?) encouraged competition in the class. Would like to see less emphasis on grades moving forward, especially since we barely received comments on the work we submitted.

This was a very valuable course, and Dana is obviously an incredibly knowledgeable instructor. There was, however, zero clarity about the ways we were being evaluated in the course, and the project grading assumptions and parameters seemed to change every week. I think it was helpful, compared to previous years, to have multiple submissions for the project, but I think the evaluation and some logistics along the way still need work.
This course is extremely time consuming and the instructor is NOT available in person.
3. The course load for this class is extremely heavy, but appropriate given how much content we are working through.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Spending time with people in the computer lab who also didn't know what they were doing.
I loved the final project. Pick something you are passionate about, because you'll be spending a lot of time on it
Great exposure to ArcGIS, terrific instructors. I like that the semester project is designed to give students a (-n ideally) professional-grade example of their capabilities.
Great introduction to the GIS. I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to work with data, predictive analytics and decision making for environmental sciences.

I really appreciated that the homework wasn't graded and that the final project was split into 4 assignments. I also appreciated when there was a chance to make our homework relevant to our final assignment. Piazza and being encouraged to help each other were also positive aspects of this course.
The knowledge and expertise of the instructor and TA.
I feel comfortable with GIS.

Dana is a great instructor who clearly was more interested in the way his students thought through a problem than he was in a "correct" solution. It allows for people to use their creativity and interest areas in assignments throughout the semester.
The homework
Learning what GIS can do. Developing a project and seeing it through completion.

I enjoyed the conceptual explanations of the software. I also found the handouts, which were prepared by the instructor, to be extremely helpful in explaining course content. I enjoyed the playful approach to some of the weekly assignments (e.g., solving a puzzle).
Very hands on homework assignments. They were really time intensive but I learned a lot from them.

The assignments,though taking a lot of time,they did help in reinforcing the concepts that had been taught in class. The project also provided an opportunity to identifying a real problem or need and use GIS as a technical tool to address the same while incorporating other externalities.
Broad survey of vector GIS techniques + an exposure to the power & extent of the program
I learned a lot from the often frustrating assignments.
Project.
The skill set is very useful, and the technology is fun to explore. It is clear that Tomlin is extraordinarily well versed in this topic and can answer any question that arises.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: This course absolutely needs to be taught in a computer lab. It is absolutely ridiculous that we are learning how to use software in a lecture when we have perfectly good computer labs on campus.
I think a few classes should be in the GIS lab so the students can follow along with Dana as he teaches.

The grading system could really stand to be re-structured. There is, if anything, a disincentive for students to put any substantial effort into weekly assignments; those that put work into weekly assignments may be at a grading disadvantage if it results in their committing less effort into the semester-long project. The lack of feedback on the semester project made this problem a larger issue; I hope the instructor will consider weighing both weekly assignments and the semester project as part of his grading for future students, because there are multiple students (myself included, to be honest) who often did well on weekly assignments but scored poorly on the graded project submissions. While I'm still happy that I took the course and feel I got a lot out of it, I already anticipate that my grade in this class will not accurately represent the amount of time and effort that I committed to the course.

More references to online materials, some guest lectures with people who apply gis to various sectors like conservation, business, policy.etc will help students network and learn more about people already applying gis Also, including some learning of open-source softwares like QGIS would be ideal.
Clarity of grading

More TA office hours or more TA's with different office hours. Alternatively maybe there could be an optional lab component where students can get started on the homework for an hour after class with a TA or the professor present.
Transparency in the grading process and goals of assignments and the class.
Some of the handouts were not complete, and the handouts were very important to the learning process.

The lecture structure of the class was difficult. I often found myself following along well in class, but since I hadn't been able to use the tools on my own computer, the knowledge was lost rather quickly. Because of the way I think and learn, I would have preferred more "problem-solving" assignments. Dana intentionally left assignment guidelines vague and open-ended to see how each student would interpret it, but this created confusion for me and some other students. I prompt with which to respond to was much easier for me to grasp and learn from.
The grading

I found that Professor Tomlin's lectures were tangentially related to the homework we had to do. It places the onus on the student to spend 15-20 hours each week doing the homework without much guidance, in order to meet the requirements of the course. A number of us spent many frustrated hours in front of a computer...hoping and wishing that we had received more guidance in class. StatLab consultants are absolutely necessary. There is a huge opportunity cost to this course; as a student I felt that I am spending unequal amount of time on this course, missing out on other academic opportunities at Yale. Maybe people who have taken GIS before spent less time on the homework, but for those of us new to GIS (many students were), it required a lot of time. And the homework is not even graded, so I'm not sure if the time spent is worth it. Yet, we feel compelled to give our best and that is taken advantage of. The TA also needs more hours with students. There is a line of people asking for and seeking help from the TA. I would also ask Professor Tomlin to please connect the tutorials in the agendas more directly with the homework, so we have some guidance on how to approach the HW.
Timely grading and feedback.

I wish there was more training about how to ask visual questions and be a creative visual thinker. Would have enjoyed assignments that were integrated into the hands-on GIS work that let us read case studies or look at professional mapping blogs for inspiration.
The grading for the course (3 credits) is not commensurate with the workload of the course.It should be higher.
Clarity of grading, continuity of workflow, a stronger syllabus with specific grade and evaluation measures

A clearer understanding of the grading structure, metrics for evaluation, and timeline would have been helpful. It seemed like some major parts of our assignments changed and the material we were being graded on wasn't always clear.
Make submissions due earlier in semester, not all crowded at the end.
Homework assignments should be completely scrapped as soon as student s begin working on their projects.
Instructor's availability
For the final project, there was not nearly enough time between grades being distributed and subsequent parts being due.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: THERE NEEDS TO BE A LAB SECTION!
Descriptions in class could be more clear.
Yes, course lectures translated directly to hw assignments.
Course lecture was not that helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I used this course heavily in analyzing my summer research data.

I took one GIS course in college, which I think helped me at the beginning of the class. But people with no GIS experience were totally fine. I don't plan on using GIS in my career (I don't think), but it is a great skill to know and market.
I am studying urban planning, so this course gave me an excellent skill moving forward.
GIS is very applicable to all aspects of field work.
It fits. Looking at parcel data is important, as is making spatial data visually interesting.
Happy I took the course, however, I think it may be my only GIS course while at FES since I'm not sure I want to take up another course slot with something I may not directly be using.
This will be a great technical/analytical skill to incorporate into future research projects.

There is often need to convince and persuade people to take stand for or against a particular thought/opinion or idea.This requires better tools beyond the ordinary to do so by creating a a clear visualization of the phenomena in question.Having a knowledge of a software such as GIS is an advantage as it makes it possible to make scenarios through maps,charts and graphs which are useful when it comes to environmental issues.

This course is very helpful for students who hope to have careers that involve any type of mapping or spatial data. I am glad I took the course as GIS is a very sought-after skill for employers. I already see how I can put the skills I learned in this course to work in poster presentations, research projects, etc.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I used this course heavily in analyzing my summer research data.
I wanted to learn how to use GIS well, and present data in a compelling way. I learned a lot with this course, and I have to say, I love doing GIS.
Wanted to improve my skills in ArcGIS.
The future of agriculture lies in predictive analytics that help make smarter decisions about resources, yield forecasting, soil quality.etc. GIS is essential if not aboslutely required for all that.

GIS is a valuable tool for anyone in the environmental field. I'm hoping that my proficiency with the software will make me look more appealing to employers. I would also like to actually use GIS to help make environmental management decisions.
I worked with GIS in my past job, but didn't know how to create my own maps or databases from scratch.
It is a good skill to have.
I anticipate incorporating spatial analysis into future research.
To learn GIS -- initially for resume building, but more genuinely to learn a data processing, analysis, storage, and communication tool.

I took this course to gain skills in the use of GIS which is becoming an important tool in environmental management.I will be doing my research in summer and I will be using GIS to map out different sets of data ranging from demographic,to sales and to spread of the Microfinance Institutions in Kenya.
I've seen a lot of job announcements that mention a desire for candidates with GIS skills--I thought this would be a useful class to take.
I thought learning GIS would be helpful.
I took this course because it is a useful skill to have, but also, and perhaps more importantly, because maps are interesting and beautiful. Maps and geographic information are a side hobby of mine.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: There seems to be many things I didn't learn. Perhaps with more advanced courses, the things I didn't learn could be covered.
Yes
Definitely!
Yes!

I'm a lot better at GIS than I was at the beginning of the course. However, I do fear that my depth of understanding is not deep enough to do analysis on my own in the future. Sometimes I did processes more because I was told that was the right way to do it and not because I actually understood why.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, absolutely. I can say this one of the course that you can actually see what improvements you make at the end of the semester.
Yes, for sure.
Yes.
Yes, excellent.
Yes the course met my expectations,though it will require continuous use and practice to retain the same.
Yes. I am very happy with the skills I gained in this course.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, I have learned the basic skills I wanted to learn.
Yes. I learned SO much

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to work on the homework with other students. It was great to bounce ideas off of each other.

It was very helpful to work with a partner on the final project, because we each took in and practiced different skills better than the other. It was sometimes a waste of time, when we spent lots of time on decided how to present the data, which was just based on personal preference. Overall, working with peers throughout the course was extremely helpful.
I think everyone should do the final project in a group. It was great to have the support of a partner
NA

Working in a group complimented each others' skills.This was quite useful in the project work as it provide an opportunity to explore ways in which the skills gained in class could be applied in the real world.There are bits in which one person had a better grasp than the other and so we could share the knowledge. It was also helpful to have someone to be accountable and kept me responsible
Advantage: division of labor Disadvantage: free-riding

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure your other classes have little work, because this class will take over your life. It's also a lot easier to have ArcGIS on your computer, but it often crashes your computer, so I don't know what to tell you.

Keep up with the work. Ask lots of questions. Work in Sage lab where there is a community for technical (and emotional) support. Try to view the ambiguity of assignments as an opportunity for creativity and independence.

Definitely expect to put a lot of work into this class. Personally GIS stopped working on my computer so I spent a lot of time in CSSSI. Pick a project you'll like, because you'll be working on it a lot throughout the semester. GREAT class overall.

I guess to game the grading system better than I did -- only do enough on the weekly assignments to learn to use the tools, and instead commit your time to the semester project (assuming the grading system remains consistent).
It will change how you see data and the the advantages of spatially analysing data. You will never look at information the same way again! Highly recommend this course.

Work on projects in pairs Use Powerpoint for designing most submissions Clear your Monday & Tuesday schedules to allow time for working on submissions near other students for faster troubleshooting & exchange of ideas Use Virtual Box with an awareness of its limitations

Don't get hung up in the grading system, and don't worry about your grade. Do your best without driving yourself crazy. The software is not user friendly at all so even simple things are hard to figure out.
Be aware of how much work this course requires.
Dana's style is definitely interesting, but you will learn more from this class than you would be able to on your own.
Yes, TAKE IT!!!
Definitely try at least one GIS course to determine if you have a knack for it. Even though I did not, it is still a hard skill I can carry with me for life and therefore is more than worth it.
Be prepared for a lot of work.

Get ready to spend LOTS of time on the homework. I would recommend that make sure all or most of your homework assignments are related to your final project. This will make your life easier when it comes to project submissions. STAT LAB consultants are hugely helpful
Having a group of fellow students to discuss assignments with (when applicable) is helpful. Start your assignments early and pace yourself, especially in the beginning and very end of the term.
It's a TON of work. But I think it pays off. Balance your course load carefully with this one.

The course is quite heavy and requires so much time,especially those new to it.It is worth considering how demanding the other courses are and what will be the resultant effect if one chose GIS as well

Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the assignments and the project. The work itself isn't too cognitively demanding, but you do have to put in a lot of hours to make things work and look nice. Mastering the software involves a lot of trial and error. The explanatory documents provided by the instructor are helpful.
Take it if you are willing to sacrifice your weekends.
Please be ready to spend 10-15 hours a week.
Plan to spend lots of time each week working on assignments. Remember to have fun!
